Mathematical Formulation of Projectile Motion 1. Governing Equations of Motion Using Newton’s Second Law , considering only gravitational force (neglecting air resistance): \[ F = ma = -mg \hat{y} \] This results in two differential equations: Horizontal motion : [  rac{d^2x}{dt^2} = 0 ] Vertical motion : [  rac{d^2y}{dt^2} = -g ] 2. Solving the Equations Given initial conditions: Initial position : \((x_0, y_0) = (0, y_0)\) Initial velocity : \( v_0 \) at an angle \( 	heta \) Velocity components : [ v_{0x} = v_0 \cos	heta, \quad v_{0y} = v_0 \sin	heta ] The general solutions are: \[ x(t) = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot t \] \[ y(t) = y_0 + v_0 \sin	heta \cdot t -  rac{1}{2} g t^2 \] 3. Time of Flight The time of flight is found by solving \( y(t) = 0 \) (when the projectile returns to its initial height \( y_0 \) ). For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ 0 = v_0 \sin	heta \cdot t -  rac{1}{2} g t^2 \] Solving for \( t \) : \[ t =  rac{2 v_0 \sin	heta}{g} \] For \( y_0 
eq 0 \) , solving the quadratic equation \( y(t) = 0 \) : \[ t =  rac{v_0 \sin	heta + \sqrt{(v_0 \sin	heta)^2 + 2g y_0}}{g} \] 4. Range Calculation The horizontal range \( R \) is: For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot  rac{2 v_0 \sin	heta}{g} =  rac{v_0^2 \sin 2	heta}{g} \] For \( y_0 
eq 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos	heta \cdot t \] where \( t \) is given by the quadratic formula above. 5. Maximum Height The maximum height occurs when vertical velocity becomes zero ( \( v_y = 0 \) ): \[ H =  rac{v_0^2 \sin^2	heta}{2g} \] For \( y_0 
eq 0 \) : \[ H = y_0 +  rac{v_0^2 \sin^2	heta}{2g} \] 6. Optimal Launch Angle The launch angle that maximizes the range for \( y_0 = 0 \) is: \[ 	heta_{	ext{optimal}} = 45^\circ \] For \( y_0 > 0 \) , the optimal angle is slightly less than \( 45^\circ \) , given by: \[ 	heta_{	ext{optimal}} \approx 45^\circ -  rac{y_0}{v_0^2} \cdot k \] where \( k \) is a proportionality constant. These equations provide a complete theoretical framework for projectile motion analysis. Would you like further modifications or additional explanations?

docs.text: Using Newton’s Second Law , considering only gravitational force (neglecting air resistance): \[ F = ma = -mg \hat{y} \] This results in two differential equations: Horizontal motion : [ \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} = 0 ] Vertical motion : [ \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} = -g ]
docs.title: 1. Governing Equations of Motion

docs.text: Given initial conditions: Initial position : \((x_0, y_0) = (0, y_0)\) Initial velocity : \( v_0 \) at an angle \( \theta \) Velocity components : [ v_{0x} = v_0 \cos\theta, \quad v_{0y} = v_0 \sin\theta ] The general solutions are: \[ x(t) = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot t \] \[ y(t) = y_0 + v_0 \sin\theta \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \]
docs.title: 2. Solving the Equations

docs.text: The time of flight is found by solving \( y(t) = 0 \) (when the projectile returns to its initial height \( y_0 \) ). For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ 0 = v_0 \sin\theta \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \] Solving for \( t \) : \[ t = \frac{2 v_0 \sin\theta}{g} \] For \( y_0 \neq 0 \) , solving the quadratic equation \( y(t) = 0 \) : \[ t = \frac{v_0 \sin\theta + \sqrt{(v_0 \sin\theta)^2 + 2g y_0}}{g} \]
docs.title: 3. Time of Flight

docs.text: The horizontal range \( R \) is: For \( y_0 = 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot \frac{2 v_0 \sin\theta}{g} = \frac{v_0^2 \sin 2\theta}{g} \] For \( y_0 \neq 0 \) : \[ R = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot t \] where \( t \) is given by the quadratic formula above.
docs.title: 4. Range Calculation

docs.text: The maximum height occurs when vertical velocity becomes zero ( \( v_y = 0 \) ): \[ H = \frac{v_0^2 \sin^2\theta}{2g} \] For \( y_0 \neq 0 \) : \[ H = y_0 + \frac{v_0^2 \sin^2\theta}{2g} \]
docs.title: 5. Maximum Height

docs.text: The launch angle that maximizes the range for \( y_0 = 0 \) is: \[ \theta_{\text{optimal}} = 45^\circ \] For \( y_0 > 0 \) , the optimal angle is slightly less than \( 45^\circ \) , given by: \[ \theta_{\text{optimal}} \approx 45^\circ - \frac{y_0}{v_0^2} \cdot k \] where \( k \) is a proportionality constant. These equations provide a complete theoretical framework for projectile motion analysis. Would you like further modifications or additional explanations?
